<<Accounts>>

At the top left is the name of your budget.  Let's create a new name.  It can be as wild or as tame as you'd like it to be.

Click on the down arrow, click on Rename budget and type in the name.
highlight: budget_name

<<Accounts>>

I like it! Let's add your checking account first.  These dollars will be what you budget in just a little while.
Good to go!
Account Setup Process

<<Accounts>>

For now, let's focus on manual entry of your transactions. This helps you really focus on where your money is going.

Click "Create Local Account". Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Checking', enter the current balance of that account, and click on the purple Create button.

<<Accounts>>

Great!  Select + Add Account!

<<Accounts>>

For this step, you'll need to log into your bank and see the current balance. Come back to me when you've got that information!
highlight: add_account
Budget Summary Overview

Let's get to our next round of fun!

 Please click on the Budget button at the top left.

<<Budget>>

I'll give you a tour of your budget screen. Here you can see the current month as well as previous and future months.
I clicked calendar #3!

<<Budget>>

Let's say you want to compare several months at once. Depending on your browser zoom level, you can select up to six months at a time. Please click the third calendar icon.
highlight: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

Now you can view three months. Let's change the view so you can see a different set of months using the purple selection.  Click on different months to see the view change.

Once you're done, click on current month, as well as the first calendar icon at the top left, so that you are seeing just one month.
highlight: months_band

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled 'To Budget.'
highlight: budget_header

<<Budget>>

While you're getting to know MyBudgetCoach, just focus on the amount to budget for now.

<<Budget>>

Click on the purple number to see some options for this amount. There are multiple ways to move money around your budget.  It's meant to be completely flexible!

<<Budget>>

Let's move onto the next part!
Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system.  You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars based on your priorities.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll get to customizing these in a little while.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of your budgeted dollars.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category.  If the amount is black, that's what you have available.

<<Budget>>

Keep in mind that if you see a red number, and If you don't cover this overspending, you are at risk for overdrafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the header 'Category' at the top of the Budget Table, select the three dots. This gives you visual options - you can show and hide hidden categories and collapse or expand Category Groups.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. The rows that have bold text are called 'Category Groups.' The arrow in a Category Group row has options to Add Category in this group, Hide, Rename, or Delete.

<<Budget>>

Go ahead and start personalizing your budget.  Change the name of the Usual Expenses group to one of your choosing.

Then add a category for a regular monthly bill you pay, such as your cell phone.  No need to be perfect, you can always change the name later.

<<Budget>>

You are doing great so far!
Add Transaction

<<Accounts>>

Keep in mind that for checking account transactions, payments decrease the balance and deposits increase the balance.
Got it!

<<Accounts>>

Click "+ Add New" and select today's date.
highlight: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

For the category, select "Bills."

<<Accounts>>

Finish this transaction by selecting the check mark to turn it green.  This means that it is Cleared and processed by your bank

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance decreased by $100.
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Since this was a test transaction, let's delete it.  Hover on the left side of the date to unhide a box. Select the box to select the transaction.

<<Accounts>>

You are doing great!

<<Accounts>>

To the right hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options.

Select 'Delete' to remove that transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Briefly about me - I've been helping people set up budgets for over a year, allowing them to be less stressed over money.  Budgeting is a passion, along with my boyfriend and three dogs!

<<Accounts>>

And if you'd like one-on-one time with me, click on the Schedule Video Call button to book a chat with me.  Please note that there is a budget friendly fee for these chats, separate from MyBudgetCoach.
highlight: zoom_link

<<Accounts>>

Here are the items we will cover:

1. Account Tour & Setup
2. How to Add Transactions 
3. Budget Tour & Setup
4. Budget Skills

Database - can keep responses and reference later on; not all questions need the database capture. The second line of the response selected is the database code. If not planning to reference answer later or drive flow based on response in another section, don't need second line.

<<Accounts>> / <<Budget>>

This aligns the avatar with which screen the user should be on. If a user goes to the Budget at a step where the avatar flow has <<Accounts>>, or if the user goes to an Account while the avatar is on Budget, the user will see the following message:

 Please navigate to the Accounts {Budget} to continue our conversation (please select an account).

Please Note: There needs to be a blank line between the reference to Accounts/Budget and the text shown in the avatar window.
<font style="font-size: 12px;">One last thing before I leave you to your budgeting...</font>
Of course
<font style="font-size: 12px;">Would you answer three short questions for me? I want to make sure I continue to improve how helpful I am!</font>
I submitted the form
Great! Here's the link: https://airtable.com/appYAaDkGzB3ecOzl/shrUnpE9sHBWWDMyB
<font style="font-size: 12px;">Thanks so much! Happy budgeting!</font>
User Survey after Tutorial
<font style="font-size: 12px;">We have covered a lot of information and you are well on your way to being more in control of your finances!</font>

<font style="font-size: 12px;">If you ever want a face-to-face conversation, click on the Schedule Video Call button.  This will take you directly to my calendar; choose a date and time convenient for you, and we will have a personal chat.</font>
<font style="font-size: 12px;">If you have brief questions, feel free to send me a message by clicking on the Message link, located on the left side, closer to the top of the page.</font>
Link to giphy: https://giphy.com/gifs/cbc-schittscreek-schitts-creek-3h4Bo5fja4ZgYS0WEg
Let's get this party started!

Welcome [[user_first_name]] to MyBudgetCoach! MyBudgetCoach is a unique budgeting software that comes along with a virtual avatar. You selected, me, Christine, as your personal coach, and I'm honored!

delete_category_group: Usual Expenses
delete_category_group: Investments and Savings
create_category_group: Monthly Bills
create_category: Monthly Bills: 🏠 Rent/Mortgage (1st)
Budget Setup

You as the Coach can do as much or as little as you would like for the user. For example, if you just want to add a handful of categories, or walk them through how to edit and add themselves, that is fine. Alternatively, you could have the system build an entire budget with defined groups, and categories, so when they select the button before the template is built, it automatically updates.

Some coaches have built the table in phases, others offer the option of just groups, and the user adds categories, or the user adds everything. Full discretion to the coach!

<<Budget>>

Text to celebrate the budget table being updated

<<Budget>>

Prepare user for when they select an option, the template will be updated automatically.

<<Budget>>

Wrap-up setup

<<Budget>>

Every time you have new income, ask yourself "what does this money have to do before I get paid again?"  

This can be a guiding principle to giving each dollar a job.

<<Budget>>

Quick budgeting tip:

If you are starting in middle of month or end of month, you don't have to budget for dollars that you've already spent or that you will not need. For example, you won't have to budget an entire month of groceries if you only have five days left in the month.

<<Budget>>

As you spend money and add those transactions to your account, remember that you'll see the total spent in the Spent column on the budget table.
Don't Edit - Keep link and keep text
This is the end of the introduction conversation. A user can reset the conversation under the Manage Coach section.

<<Accounts>>

Is there a partner budgeting with you?

YES
partner = yes

NO
partner = no

Next
partner_name = [user_input]

<<Accounts>>

Ok great! Please share with me their first name.

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for sharing [[user_first_name]]. I look forward to working with you and [[partner_name]] throughout the tutorial!

<<Accounts>>

Fantastic!  As a side note, my avatar can help you add a credit card account if you regularly use credit cards.  After finishing our tour, you can Start a New Conversation and select the Add Credit Card topic.

Getting back to your checking account, let me show you how to add a transaction.

Buttons default to 'Next' if no text is added on line. Button text can be short, or long (even two sentences) and include emojis. If have multiple lines due to a question, can program button text for each line.
Consider having a question to create a break for the user. Could also reference the earlier list of steps to complete, and show progress by crossing out those pieces that are done.

<<Accounts>>

There are just a few more functions that I'd like to point out on the Account screen.

<<Accounts>>

The 'Import' button allows you to upload an export of transactions from your bank.
highlight: import_button

<<Accounts>>

The 'Filter' button allows you to filter down the transactions you are viewing by certain criteria (date, payee, category...).
highlight: filter_button

<<Accounts>>

The 'Undo' and 'Redo' buttons are helpful tools when you are working in this screen.

These buttons are available in the Budget screen as well. However, when selected, they will 'Undo' or 'Redo' your last action completed for either Accounts or Budget, depending on where your last action was.

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Search' bar.

As you type, whether text or numbers, the list of transactions will dynamically filter down based on criteria entered.
highlight: search_bar

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Split/Toggle' button. 

If you happen to have split transactions, this button will expand or collapse those transactions from view.
highlight: split_toggle_button

<<Accounts>>

These three dots show additional options.

1. Show running balance
2. Hide 'cleared' checkboxes
3. Export
4. Reconcile
5. Link account
6. Close account
highlight: more_button
Coach can decide how much explanation they want to provide for each of these. Reconciliation for example can be a complex discussion.

<<Accounts>>

Type "Cell Phone Company" as your Payee.
highlight: select_payee
highlight: select_category

<<Accounts>>

Now, enter $100 in the Payment box.
highlight: payment_input

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Add". 

Please note, you can select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.
highlight: cleared_status_icon
highlight: save_transaction
highlight: months_band
highlight: budget_table
highlight: category_column
highlight: budgeted_column
highlight: spent_column
highlight: balance_column

<<Budget>>

The rows below a Category Group heading (not the bold text) are called Categories. When you hover over a Category row, the arrow that appears gives you the option to Hide, Rename, and Delete that Category.
Very cool!

<<Budget>>

Below the categories is the 'Income' Section.

<<Budget>>

The Income row is the total amount of deposits to a checking or savings account in a month; this could also include refunds on credit cards, cash, etc. 

The Starting Balances row is calculated your first month, but then remains $0 each month after that. You can 'Hide' this category if you choose after your first month.
highlight: received_column

<<Budget>>

Also when you hover on a Category row, a small paper icon appears. Selecting this opens up a note box. This can be used to capture helpful information about that category. For example, the amount you intend to budget each month or when it's due.
Got it!

<<Budget>>

When you hover over the month at the top of the budget summary, two up arrows are shown to the left. Selecting this will collapse the budget summary view to only show the 'To Budget' amount.

You can expand by hovering over the month and then selecting the two down arrows to the left of the month.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the month there are three vertical dots. Selecting this shows additional options that can have dollars budgeted to all your categories in one click.

<<Budget>>

These options include:

1. Copy last month's budget
2. Set budgets to zero (this resets any budgeted dollars back to zero)
3. Set budgets to 3 month average
highlight: budget_more_button

All boxes don't need to have <<Accounts>> or <<Budget>>. If you remove this, that means the user can be in either screen and the avatar will continue. This can help with transitions from one section to another.

<<Budget>>

Let's move now to how to go about budgeting your dollars and how to give every dollar a job!

<<Budget>>

You should now have a good understanding on how to use the Budget.  Great job!
This section could be very extensive, or you could keep it high level and create a separate conversation the next time the user gets paid.
highlight: selected_transactions_button

<<Accounts>>

My avatar is here to walk you through the basic functions of MyBudgetCoach.  If you get stuck, feel free to send me any questions via the Messages link, located on the left close to the top, and I'll get back to you within one to two days.

Order of Walk-Through

Can organize your conversation to have Budget table overview first (no numbers so simpler with less questions) then Accounts OR you could have Accounts first and then have Budget Table.
For Link Account, consider offering a launch to the Import Transaction Options conversation.
HelpScout Articles: Footer of MyBudgetCoach.com; Company; Knowledge Base
Budget Skills
Credit Cards get added in a separate conversation. For the Intro, just focus on Checking account. Feel free to let your user know Credit Cards can be added later on in a separate conversation.
Let's Go!

<<Accounts>>

And with that, are you ready to dive in?
need help with this gif

<<Accounts>>

Okay, no problem!  You can pick back up here when you are ready!

<<Accounts>>

Great, let's keep moving forward
Nope, good to continue

<<Accounts>>

Do you need a break?

<<Budget>>

Let's say you need to put gas in your vehicle soon and you estimate it will be $40.

Select the To Budget number.  Click on 'Move to a category'.  Type 40 in the box and select the appropriate category, and click the purple Transfer button.

<<Budget>>

You will see that for this category, your Budgeted amount is $40 and so is your Balance.  

Continue this decision making process until your To Budget number is $0.

<<Budget>>

When you see a red number, don't be too hard on yourself; life happens and it's totally understandable!

In this situation, you will want to transfer money from another category to cover this overspending.  Click on the Balance from one positive category, type the amount to move, select the overspent category, and click on Transfer.
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>>

Any number that is black in the Balance column is available for you to spend for that category.  

It doesn't necessarily mean that you have to spend it, but it's available if you need it.
highlight: zoom_link

<<Budget>>

Quick tip:

When naming a category, add the due date (such as Electricity - 1st).  This will help you prioritize on how to budget your dollars.
highlight: balance_column

<<Accounts>>

You can pause our conversation by clicking the 'X' at the top corner of my avatar.  And then click on the white 'Continue conversation..' box to the left to pick up where we left off.

<<Accounts>>

You'll see some options (all great):

1. Create local account, which will require manual entry of all transactions or

2. Sync all transactions automatically by connecting your bank account to MyBudgetCoach (please note there is an small fee for this)

We will be using option 1 for our set-up.
I'm ready!

<<Budget>>

The spent amount is subtracted from what was budgeted, giving you the balance.  A red number means that category is overspent and a positive black number means there is still money available.
highlight: messages_link
highlight: messages_link

<<Accounts>>

Clicking the Back button allows you to review previous topics or steps.
Thanks for the info!

<<Budget>>

And if don't have any categories that can cover overspending, then let's chat about it.

Reach out to me via the Messages link, or click on the Schedule Video Call for a live conversation.  I'm here to help you in any way that I can!
Thanks for the reminder!

<<Accounts>>

At the bottom right hand corner of this open conversation, you will see three vertical dots.  Clicking on the dots gives you these options:

1. Give Feedback
2. Reset This Conversation
3. End This Conversation

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for your answer! Let's add one more account to capture your total expenses.

<<Accounts>>

Select "+Add Account", click "Create Local Account."

Name your account, select a Type of "For Budget: Credit Card", and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Budget>>

You want to plan on Budgeting dollars to make a payment of at least your minimum payment for each account.

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for your answer! Let's now add the credit card account that is used the most often of your remaining accounts.

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Accounts>>

That wraps up adding accounts. Let's move now to adding transactions on a credit card account.

<<Accounts>>

How many transactions per week occur on your remaining credit card account?

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.
highlight: selected_transactions_button

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Accounts>>

As you continue to use MyBudgetCoach, please keep in mind each account requires reconciliation, a few times a week, and categorizing of transactions.

Great work learning the differences with credit card transactions. The next portion of this section is to review the impact to the Budget Summary and Table as a result of adding credit card account(s).
Got it
5 or Less transactions

<<Budget>>

Because you will be carrying some debt over to next month, there a few additional steps we will walk through to make sure MyBudgetCoach works properly for you.

<<Accounts>>

If at a later point you would like to add additional credit card accounts, you can select this conversation again to start from the beginning.

<<Accounts>>

Based on the number of transactions that occur per week, I would recommend leaving out the additional account for now, and then if you would like to add it on a future date, feel free!
Yes; Let's review those steps again

<<Accounts>>

Based on the number of transactions that occur per week, let's add one more account so your expenses can be accurately captured each month.
No; All set

Congratulations on setting up a credit card in the Budget!

Is there another Credit Card account where you would like to walk through the Budget set-up process again?
Let's now move to Step 2. For this, we will shift from the Budget to the Accounts section and select a credit card account.
More than 5 transactions
Ok! My credit card account category has been added. Step 1 complete!

<<Accounts>>

To summarize, you have added three credit card accounts.

<<Budget>>

Sure; Before we review those steps again, please create a new category within your Credit Card Group and name that category with the Credit Card Account name.
highlight: balance column

<<Accounts>>

How many additional credit
cards do you actively use each week?

<<Budget>>

Now that you have added credit card account(s), your 'To Budget' number has been reduced by the total of the balance for the account(s) you just added. Let's walk through how to make the 'To Budget' number equal to what it was prior to adding the credit card account(s).
Two or more

<<Accounts>>

Let's add your credit card account that is the most used card first.

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance. Come back to me when you've got that information!
highlight: add_account

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.
move_to: budget_header
highlight: add_account

Thanks for selecting the Add Credit Card conversation!

This conversation walks through the steps for how to add a credit card account. Whether you are new MyBudgetCoach user, or a long-term user that now needs to add a credit card account, this conversation is meant for you.

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.
highlight: zoom_link

<<Accounts>>

Before we link a third credit card account, let me ask a follow-up question.
highlight: add_account

<<Budget>>

Because you can pay the balance in-full, and have a credit card category with a 'Balance' = 0, moving forward with your MyBudgetCoach use, you will be funding your categories outside of the credit card category. If you aren't accumulating any debt, have covered any overspent categories, than your credit card payment will be equal to your current balance.
highlight: add_account

For the credit card account(s) you added, are there any that you plan to pay off the current balance at the end of this month?

Please note, by 'current balance' I am referring to the balance you entered when you added the account. This is not the statement balance, which is a balance as of an earlier date.
You can complete the 'Calculate Credit Card Payment' conversation at any time to assist in determining what your credit card payment should be.

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.

<<Budget>>

Give yourself some grace and remember, reducing your debt is a journey and takes dedication. You already have started working toward your goal by using this budgeting software and working through this conversation to learn more!

<<Budget>>

If you have more than one credit card account, you will need to complete the following steps for each account.

<<Budget>>

Step 1 is to create a Category Group called 'Credit Cards.' Under that Category Group, you would add a Category for each of the credit card account(s) you added.

Let me add this for you as a starting point...

<<Budget>>

OK! Step 1 is completed. Please scroll down to the bottom of your budget table to find the Credit Card category group and rename the newly created category to your specific credit card account name.

create_category_group: Credit Cards
create_category: Credit Cards: Credit Card Account

<<Accounts>>

The first transaction should be the transaction that was added when you first added the account. You should see an amount in the 'Payment' column that equals the balance on the day you added the account.

<<Accounts>>

Now that we have created the category on the Budget for the Credit Card Account, we are going to change the Category from 'Starting Balance' to the newly created category for your Credit Card Account.
Great work! Now, lets go back to the Budget and see what happened with the 'Spent' and 'Balance' columns in the Credit Card Account category.

<<Budget>>

Scroll down to the credit card category of the account you just updated. Now the 'Spent' column is a negative number that equals your balance you entered previously.

<<Budget>>

Since the 'Budgeted' column for the category is 0, the 'Balance' is a negative red number and is equal to 'Spent.'
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>>

The last step, Step 3, is to complete the actions for how you want MyBudgetCoach to handle the debt associated with the credit card. You have some options, so let me first ask you a question so I can tailor my guidance.

<<Budget>>

Good for you! KUDOS on managing your debt. Very few people with a credit card balance have the cash flow to pay in-full at any time.

<<Budget>>

To fund your balance you enter the amount of your credit card balance in the Budgeted column of your newly created credit card category. This will update the 'Balance' to be 0 since you budgeted dollars to equal the current balance of the credit card.

<<Budget>>

When you Budgeted the dollars, the purple number at the top of the Budget Summary in the 'To Budget' went down.

<<Budget>>

You can now budget with confidence the rest of your available dollars to your remaining categories, until your 'To Budget' number is 0. If you would like to learn more about this process, select the 'Make To Budget Equal to 0' conversation to work through that conversation when you have completed this conversation.

<<Budget>>

We need to allow the remaining balance you don't pay off this current month, to continue to future months, since your credit card company will continue to have that balance carry over until you pay it off.

<<Budget>>

MyBudgetCoach has a unique feature that is called 'Rollover overspending.' This option allows a user to have the debt continue into future months, instead of paying off this month, so you can pay it off overtime.

<<Budget>>

Selecting the 'Rollover overspending' option increases your 'To Budget' number in the current month, since the debt has now been rolled over to future months.

<<Budget>>

Select the negative amount in red text in the Balance column of your Credit Card Account Category. Within the option menu that comes up, select the 'Rollover overspending' option.

To see the system roll the debt over to a future month, select the option in the top left to show two months at a time by selecting the 2nd calendar icon.

<<Budget>>

The arrow to the right of the amount in the Balance column is how MyBudgetCoach alerts you to the fact you have rolled over the overspending for future months. This option will stay turned on for all future months, unless you select to 'Remove overspending rollover.'

<<Budget>>

When you budget to the category it reduces the debt immediately. You'll still have to submit a payment through your credit card account, but you can see your progress in the category right away.

<<Budget>>

To handle interest applied to your credit card account(s), if applicable, you would categorize that transaction to the Category of your Credit Card Account, just like how you updated the Starting Balance category.

<<Budget>>

Credit Cards can be complex, especially if you have more than one credit card account. I am available for a one-on-one call at your convenience to help answer any questions you may have in your future use of MyBudgetCoach.

<<Accounts>>

The important difference between a bank account and a credit card account is that for a credit card account, Payments INCREASE the balance, and Deposits DECREASE the balance. This is because a credit card balance is negative.

<<Accounts>>

Please select your main credit card account. You will now add two hypothetical transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Please select '+ Add New,' select today's date and enter a Payee of 'Cell Phone Company.'

<<Accounts>>

Select an applicable category and enter a Payment amount of 100, Clear the transaction, and select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now add a transaction for a credit card payment. Credit Card payments are Transfers and entered as a Deposit.

<<Accounts>>

The credit card balance, a red negative number, has now increased by 100.

<<Accounts>>

Please select '+ Add New,' select today's date, and for the Payee, select 'Make Transfer.' Within the 'Transfer To/From' list of accounts, select your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

The Category field is now populated with Transfer. Enter 100 in the 'Deposit' field, since this is a payment to reduce the credit card balance, and select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now jump over to the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Since you selected 'Make Transfer' as the Payee in your credit card account, this automatically added a transaction to your checking account as well.

<<Accounts>>

Please take note that the credit card payment is an outflow in the Payment column for the checking account, but an inflow in the Deposit column for the credit card. This is because your payment reduces a negative balance (Deposit) in the credit card account and reduces the positive balance (Payment) in the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

KUDOS on creating transactions for both accounts!

<<Accounts>>

Before we move to the next step, let's delete those two credit card transactions you added.

<<Accounts>>

Please navigate back to your main credit card account and select each of the two transactions using the box to the left of the date. Then select the link named '2 transactions' to the right of the search bar and choose Delete.
highlight: add_new_button

Roll up your sleeves! The following is a summary for what we will complete. 

1. Adding Credit Card Account(s)
2. Adding Credit Card transactions
3. Updating Budget Table based on pay off plan
4. Determining your current debt management strategy

Please select 'All Accounts' to continue the conversation.
Thanks for your help!
Great work setting up your Credit Card accounts in MyBudgetCoach! This ends this conversation. Bye for now...

<<Accounts>>

Which Option would you like to learn more about?
SIMPLE FIN
Direct Import
Bulk Import

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for that information. Direct Import within MyBudgetCoach has some great benefits. For example, the starting balance for linked accounts is automatically set and the system includes three prior days worth of transactions to get you started.

<<Accounts>>

Direct Import removes the additional tasks of having to manually upload transactions. Each time you log in, the system will automatically have added recent transactions.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach uses machine learning, so as you continue to use the system, the system will automatically apply proposed categories to new transactions and the manual steps to categorize transactions will lessen over time.

<<Accounts>>

To increase your security, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with a third-party service, SimpleFIN, to link your accounts. SimpleFIN uses a well-established connection software called 'MX' to connect your bank account financial institutions to SimpleFIN.

<<Accounts>>

To connect SimpleFIN to MyBudgetCoach, there is a one-time code produced by SimpleFIN to enter into MyBudgetCoach. The accounts you link in SimpleFIN will then become available to link to already existing accounts within MyBudgetCoach to start Direct Import.

<<Accounts>>

Please note SimpleFIN does have a small additional fee: $1.50 per month, or $15 per year (not including tax, if applicable). This is paid separately from your MyBudgetCoach subscription and is paid through SimpleFIN, not within MyBudgetCoach.
I'm good, thanks!

<<Accounts>>

The Bulk Import process requires you to export/download transactions from your financial institution in a 'csv' file format.
Have you completed an export of transactions from a bank or credit card account before?

<<Accounts>>

Understood! I think it would be best to talk through this further during a one-on-one call with me. I would be happy to walk you through the steps to complete the export of transactions and how to load them to MyBudgetCoach.
Ok great! Are you familiar with how to edit column headings and re-arrange amounts in columns within Excel?

<<Accounts>>

Be sure your columns are organized in the following order:

Date / Payee / Notes / Category (blank) / Amount

The amount can either be one column, or split into separate columns, one for Payments and one for Deposits.

MyBudgetCoach can also split up the amount column into two separate columns by splitting the positive and negative values.

<<Accounts>>

Once you have your data organized the correct way, use the 'Import' button to select your csv file to upload. Follow along the MyBudgetCoach screen to select the appropriate column in your csv file to map to the correct MyBudgetCoach field.

<<Accounts>>

Great job importing your transactions! You can complete these steps at your chosen frequency. I recommend at least once a week until you become comfortable with the software.
Bulk Import

Thanks for selecting the Import Transaction Options conversation!

In this conversation, we will walk through the different methods for adding transactions within MyBudgetCoach.

There are three options:

Option 1: Adding transactions manually (the Introduction conversation walked through this process),

Option 2: Direct Import - using a third-party bank connection software, SimpleFIN. Once completed, when you select 'Sync' transactions will automatically be brought into MyBudgetCoach for all accounts.

Option 3: Bulk Import - uploading exports of transactions from your bank to MyBudgetCoach to add transactions in bulk for each account.

Thanks for selecting the Make To Budget Equal to 0 conversation!

When in your Budget, the 'To Budget' number is critical to monitor. If it is positive, you have dollars left that need a job in the current month. If it is negative, you over budgeted, and need to take money back. If it is 0, you have successfully balanced your budget. This conversation will provide guidance for how to update the 'To Budget' amount.

<<Budget>>

Please review the 'Balance' amount in your non-Credit Card categories. If the 'Balance' is greater than 0, consider whether the amount you entered in the Budget column is required now prior to receiving your next source of income.

<<Budget>>

You can move money between categories, or back to the 'To Budget' number, by selecting the amount in the 'Balance' column. Please be sure you maintain enough money in the 'Balance' for categories that have future expenses due to be paid from your checking account.

When you have moved your available money, come back to continue.
No; It remains a negative red number
No; The 'To Budget' is now a positive purple amount.

<<Budget>>

Is your 'To Budget' equal to 0?

<<Budget>>

You can add money to the 'Budgeted' column for each category with the following methods.

1) Typing the amount in the Budgeted column and selecting 'Enter.'
2) Select the 'To Budget' number and select the 'Move to a Category' option to enter an amount and select a category to move the money.

When you are done funding these expenses, come back to the conversation to continue.
This is the end of this conversation. Great work having your 'To Budget' amount be equal to 0!

Start the Add Credit Card conversation

Select the 'Start the Add Credit Card conversation' button below. This will automatically close this conversation, and bring you to the 'Add Credit Card' conversation automatically.

You can tell which conversation you are currently working through by reviewing the open conversations on the left hand menu and finding the words under the title of the conversation.

If you see the words 'In progress...' this is the conversation you are currently working through. If you see the words 'Continue conversation...' this is a conversation you have started, but not yet completed.

If you are trying to re-start a conversation, please select the three vertical dots in the bottom right and select the 'Reset This Conversation' option.

How are you adding transactions in your MyBudgetCoach accounts?
Ok! Wait a few days for the payment to be posted to your credit card and bank accounts.
You may need to categorize the transaction as a 'Transfer' if MyBudgetCoach doesn't do this automatically.

<<Accounts>>

When reviewing your Credit Card account transactions, locate (or add) the row for the payment and adjust the Payee by selecting 'Make Transfer.' Within the 'Transfer To/From' list of accounts, select your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

The Category field is now populated with Transfer. The amount in the 'Deposit' column, equal to the payment amount, reduces the credit card balance. Select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now jump over to the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Since you selected 'Make Transfer' as the Payee in your credit card account, this automatically added a transaction to your checking account as well. Double check if a duplicate Payment transaction exists on your account. If there is one, delete it so the transaction with the 'Transfer' is the only payment transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Please take note that the 'Payment' field is populated for the checking account, which reduces the balance. However, the credit card account has the Deposit field populated because an inflow to a negative balance reduces the negative balance.

If the two numbers are far off, or the credit card category Balance amount is a higher negative number than the current balance of your credit card account, please book a video call with me.

You need some help reconciling? No problem. I got you.

<<Accounts>>

The first thing you need to do is figure out what your target balance is. By that I mean, what is the balance in real life that we are matching your MBC account to.
I'm in

<<Accounts>>

Log in to your account in real life.
I'm confident I see it

<<Accounts>>

Ok, you are looking for the most recent "cleared balance." That's the balance that does not include the pending charges. It might also be called the "current balance" or the "posted balance."

Next
balance = [user_input]

<<Accounts>>

Great work. Now we will tell MBC what your current balance is.

If you are reconciling a credit card account, please enter the balance as a negative number.
Ok, I got it

<<Accounts>>

For me, the easiest place to find the balance we need is in the list of recent transactions. Typically there's a section of pending transactions and below that there's all the cleared transactions. Often beside each cleared transaction it'll show the balance after those transactions. Or sometimes it shows it above each day's list of transactions.
Got it

<<Accounts>>

Since it's a credit card account almost always the pending transactions aren't included in the main balance that is displayed. So you can use that most prominently displayed balance.
Find the cleared balance
highlight: more_button
I did that and now there's a box that says "your cleared balance...
I did that and now it says "all reconciled"

<<Accounts>>

Click the more button and then "Reconcile" in the account you're working on.

Enter [[balance]] in the box and press reconcile.

<<Accounts>>

Ok, so currently your MBC account and your real life account don't match, so let's figure out why.
See you next time
I need to reconcile another account

<<Accounts>>

The number you entered matched your MBC account. Awesome. Click "Done Reconciling" and celebrate.

<<Accounts>>

Click here to show the cleared/uncleared totals for your account balance. We want to be able to see those numbers.
"All reconciled!"
Your cleared balance...

<<Accounts>>

Now that everything is marked as cleared that should be, look at the reconciliation dialog. What does it say?
I'm all done now
I need to reconcile another account
I'll book a call
I'd like to give it a try.

<<Accounts>>

At this point you'll need to look for missing, duplicated, mis-typed or otherwise incorrect transactions. I can walk you through some things to look for or you can book a call with me and we can tackle this together.
See you soon

<<Accounts>>

Great, I'll see you soon. In the meantime keep up with entering and categorizing transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Ok, start from the date you last reconciled. You can tell because the cleared/uncleared icon will be a green lock for reconciled transactions.
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Cleared balance represents cleared transactions and uncleared are pending transactions. When we reconcile we are only concerned with cleared transactions, since pending ones can change.

<<Accounts>>

If you look in the far right column,  you'll see little buttons beside each transaction. These indicate if the transaction has cleared the bank (green) or not (grey).
highlight: cleared_status_icon

<<Accounts>>

If you enter transactions manually then you also have to click these buttons when you notice a charge has cleared. If you use import you won't have to click them most of the time but might need to mange a few recent ones when you reconcile.
Click the button
Troubleshoot: uncleared

<<Accounts>>

Go ahead and turn these icons green for anything that is no longer pending in real life, leave them grey if they are still pending. As you do that you should see the cleared balance at the top of the screen change, and you'll also see the dialog about reconciling change as well.
highlight: zoom_link

<<Accounts>>

Find that date in your bank as well as your budget account. Look at your bank and go in the order of the transactions there. Check for each one in your budget and check them off (far left of each transaction) as you find them.

<<Accounts>>

Add any transactions that were missed and delete any that are extras. Fix typos if you find them. Also make sure outflows are in the payment column and inflows in the deposit column.

<<Accounts>>

As you go along you can sometimes check the balance at the end of each day against the balance in real life at the end of that day. This will only work if your dates match for each transaction though.
I'm making progress
It's confusing

<<Accounts>>

How's this working so far?

<<Accounts>>

Great, keep it up until you get to the current date.
Yes, I'm doing that now

<<Accounts>>

I get that. It can be a tricky skill to learn. Would you like to book a call?
It sure does
Still no

<<Accounts>>

Look at the reconciliation dialog. Does the reconciliation dialog say "All reconciled!" now?
I'm all done now
I need to reconcile another account
Yes please

<<Accounts>>

There is an option to let the program adjust the balance instead of finding the error. Shall we go ahead and do that?
Is there another option?
Troubleshoot: line by line
highlight: zoom_link
Thanks for your help.

<<Accounts>>

In your reconciliation dialog box there should be a button that says "create reconcilation transaction." Go ahead and click that. Then click "Done Reconciling."

Will you be reconciling a credit card account or a bank account?
which_account = bank
which_account = credit
I'm unsure if I'm looking at the right place

<<Accounts>>

Thanks! I ask because different types of accounts show balances differently.

<<Accounts>>

It could also be possible that there is a transaction in your bank account, that you don't see in MyBudgetCoach, pending or cleared. In this case, manually add that transaction(s) to ensure all the transactions that are cleared are included in MyBudgetCoach.
highlight: cleared_status_icon

<<Accounts>>

You're now all set to move forward. Be sure to reconcile often moving forward, 2-3 times per week, and hopefully you'll be able to find errors and not have to make adjustments.
